properties.chapter: Bodleian Library MS. Ousley Add. 176 fol. 337b
properties.source-credit: Oxford, Bodleian Library MS. Ouseley Add. 176:
properties.description:
This illustration or painting is from The Shahnama, Book of Kings, made by Ferdowsi Tousi, a great Persian poet and one of the greatest Persian poets who ever walked on earth. Ferdowsi Tousi is the creator of the great epic poem, one of the longest epic poems in the world named The Shahnameh or Book of Kings. 
The Shahnameh, is in term a story book where it entails the history and mythical past of the Iran, from the beginning of civilization until the Islamic conquest of Iran in the 7th century. 
The Shahnameh, is originally written in Persian language, but many scholars have translated The Shahnameh into English language translation with different interpretation. The Shahnameh produced knowledge about cultural values, history, and background on Zoroastrianism. An ancient religion and one of the oldest religions that was founded by Zoroaster. According to the Shahnameh, Ferdowsi website, ‘’In short: A study of the Shahnameh gives us a literary excuse for exploring how culture moves across time and space, becoming part of the global common heritage.’’ (Ferdowsi, 2016). The Shahnameh or Book of Kings includes 990 chapters, and 62 stories. Isn’t that interesting? This document will explain the summary and the meaning of the illustration of The Shahnameh.

properties.chapter: Chapter 2: Bahram Gur Hunts in the Company of Azada Story
properties.source-credit: Oxford, Bodleian Library MS. Ouseley Add. 176:
properties.description: Bahram Gur hunts in the company of Azada, 337b, Vol VI, Pg 382-83. This shows Bahram Gur as a young prince hunting while being accompanied by Azada, a slave girl who was a musician as we see that Azada is holding a harp while Bahram Gur hunts the Gazelle with bow and arrow, and ‘his heart’s delight and desire.’ Azada challenged Bahram Gur to prove his abilities as a hunter and turn the male gazelle into a female, and a female one into male, then combining them together by pinning the foot and ear of another Gazelle by using his bow to fire and hunt them. Bahram Gur then shot two successful shots from his arrow into the head of a female deer and hit the male deer with a double pointed arrow on his antlers and cut the antlers off. He then went for the third gazelle and scratched or hit the ear of that third gazelle, and when the third gazelle tried to scratch it by using her foot and raising it to scratch it, Bahram Gur pinned the foot and ear together of the Gazelle. An accusation was surrounding the prince’s skill, prowess, and fame because Azada reached his success and reputation because of demonic powers. A legitimate and honorific Persian ruler should be successful in hunt and indispensable as a Persian ruler, which the royal charisma demonstrated. Bahram Gur became angry and threw Azada from the camel and smashed her.

properties.chapter: Chapter 3: The Harp in the hands of Azada
Chapter 4: The Bow and Arrow, Weapon of Bahram Gur
Chapter 5: The Gazelle as a prey from the predator
properties.description: In the Bahram Gur Hunts in the Company of Azada image, we see Bahram Gur hunting the Gazelle with his bow and arrow. Azada challenged Bahram Gur to prove his skill as a hunter and hunt the Gazelle. In the image, Bahram Gur appears to hunt and killed the Gazelle with his bow and arrow as a weapon of choice. It is interesting that Bahram Gur used bow and arrow, a long-range weapon instead of a short range weapon such as a sword, a spear, or a shield. You know why? Because the Gazelle is known as a prey, however, the only weapon that the Gazelle have in order to protect themselves is their speed. Gazelle is one of the fastest animals that ever existed, it can run up to 60 mph, imagine that speed! A Gazelle can also leap or jump high like a spring. So, if Bahram Gur wants to prove himself and define his skill as a hunter, hunting a Gazelle would fit into that kind of category. A Gazelle can also be eaten, their meat is the same kind of meat as a deer, therefore as a hunter that Bahram Gur is, hunting a Gazelle proves his worth and skill as a hunter, in addition, can eat the Gazelle afterwards as what hunters usually do after hunting their prey.

properties.chapter: Chapter 6: The transportation and ride of Bahram Gur
properties.description:
In the image, Bahram Gur is seen riding a camel while hunting the Gazelle, but why? A common misconception is that a camel is slow, but why is Bahram Gur used a camel as mode of transportation especially when hunting? A camel can run up to the maximum speed of 40 mph or 67 kph. In addition, a common misconception is that the camel can and should be ridden in a hot climate country such as the middle east where hot summer and desserts are present. However, a camel can also survive and adopt to cold temperatures such as -29 degrees Celsius. The diet of a camel also is easy to maintain as they are not picky, they can eat whatever is possible, any grass or even cactuses will do. And lastly, a camel can grow up to 6 feet, giving the master or the owner an advantage of height to whatever they are hunting, so if Bahram Gur combines the bow and arrow, a long-range weapon and a camel that is 6 feet tall, the range and the visibility of Bahram Gur while hunting the Gazelle will be much easier to hunt that riding a horse. A possible reason why Bahram Gur chose a camel to hunt the Gazelle. 

The setting of the book Shahnameh is also in the middle eastern, therefore the mode of transportation present in that location is a camel.

Can you see the beautiful calligraphy writing above the image of Bahram Gur Hunts in the Company of Azada? That writing or calligraphy is called Nasta’liq script, a beautiful Persian calligraphy writing. It is quite elegant that the strokes involves bold lines to produce an alphabet. 
The Nasta’liq script or the Persian writing is used and involved in the Shahnameh, Book of Kings by Ferdowsi. In the book, you can see the writing depicting the image corresponding to it, describing and making the image more meaningful and elegant because of the stroke that the calligraphy writing provides. In addition, as time passes by, the Nasta’liq script continues to evolve into more contemporary modern style. There is also a new genre of writing the Nasta’liq script which transforms it into a cursive form of writing. The Nasta’liq script or the Persian calligraphy writing continues to evolve into a modern and contemporary way, and until now, is being used by artist as it is considered as a form of art. An elegant way of writing and describing certain things when being used, from what I observed the strokes have some similarities with writings from ancient China and Japan and uses bold lines and strokes to form an alphabet.

<Vera, John Kim/ARTH 370 Student> (Researcher, Scriptwriter, Storyboarder, Audio Editor, Image Editor) and Hussein Keshani (Coder). “Bahram Gur hunts in the company of Azada.” In Firdausi’s Shahnama: A Digital Art History Student Project, edited by Hussein Keshani, November 30, 2022.
